title: Audiologic Management of a Patient with Sickle Cell Disease
chief_complaint: I've been having hearing loss and pain in my right ear for about 6 months. It's hard to hear my instructors in class.

problem_summary.onset: Approximately 6 months prior to initial evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating hearing loss; symptoms worsened over time.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear initially; bilateral involvement noted at follow-up.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otalgia (right ear), chronic fatigue, joint pain, swelling of feet.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing instructors in a university setting.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is a college student on scholarship seeking an education degree; needs to hear for class.

history.present_illness: Patient reports fluctuating hearing loss and pain in the right ear for the past 6 months. Previously seen by NP for ear infection and treated with antibiotics; hearing improved but did not return to normal.
history.otologic_history: Positive for chronic upper respiratory infections. Negative for tinnitus, vertigo, or head trauma.
history.prior_management: Prescribed antibiotics by student health clinic prior to referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows mild-to-moderately severe SNHL. Left ear thresholds are within normal limits.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs agree with PTA. Right ear WRS shows rollover (PB-PI Rollover Index 0.27), suggestive of cochlear pathology.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume and static admittance bilaterally. Left ear normal pressure; Right ear negative pressure.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Consistent with cochlear hearing loss in the right ear (obtained at reduced sensation levels). Normal sensation levels in the left ear. No decay observed.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: ABR: Normal absolute and interwave latencies; Wave V repeatable. DPOAEs: Absent through 2000 Hz in right ear; present/normal in left ear >2000 Hz.

history.present_illness: Patient presented with severe joint pain and fever (101.2 F). Reported recently observed changes in hearing sensitivity.
history.medical_psych_history: Inter-visit medical workup revealed 28% hemoglobin S, confirming Sickle Cell Disease (SCD). Patient reports chronic swelling of feet, fatigue, and achy joints since childhood.
history.prior_management: Referred to otologist and rheumatologist between visits.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear now shows slight mid-frequency SNHL. Right ear shows significant decrease in thresholds at 2000-8000 Hz compared to baseline.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear mild to moderately severe loss in ability to receive speech. Left ear normal ability.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, middle ear pressure, and static compliance bilaterally.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: DPOAEs: Absent at high frequencies in left ear and mid-frequencies in right ear. ABR could not be completed due to patient discomfort.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a fluctuating, asymmetrical sensorineural hearing loss that has progressed over a one-month period. Initially, the right ear exhibited mild-to-moderately severe SNHL with rollover, while the left ear was normal. Follow-up testing revealed worsening high-frequency thresholds in the right ear and new slight mid-frequency SNHL in the left ear, coincident with a Sickle Cell Disease pain crisis.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss appears to be related to the Sickle Cell Disease diagnosis, likely due to reduced blood flow to the inner ear.
Because you are currently in a pain crisis with a fever, you need to see your SCD specialist immediately.
We see some changes in your hearing today compared to last month, including a slight change in your left ear.
Once your current medical crisis is managed, please return for a re-evaluation and we can discuss hearing aids to help with your classes.
notes_for_actor: In the first visit, you are concerned about school and the pain in your right ear.
In the second visit, you are in significant physical distress (pain crisis), feverish, and uncomfortable. You may be impatient with testing due to body pain.
